Author: xirium
Content:
While it is possible to find bug.com or even snufflebug.com you are unlikely to find which is better than snuffle and is also available. Indeed, I'm becoming quite partial to snuffle because the word is similar to both snafu ( http://www.catb.org/~esr/jargon/html/S/SNAFU-principle.html ) and muffle; going from a very bad situation to greatly reducing unwanted side-effects.

I suppose you could choose mufflebug.com but would either of us thought of it if we hadn't seen snufflebug.com?

Author: aneesh
Content:
Exactly. Random Google searches aren't the way to attract people to such conferences. But an invitation from a friend with similar interests also attending the conference is! facebook 1, Google 0.

If you think about it, what is Google the way to do? Anything involving people, and facebook wins. Flickr is Google-searchable. Facebook Photos is not. But facebook Photos wins, at least among young adults.

Author: axod
Content:
Are you seriously saying you think 'snufflebug' is the only one?

Get a dictionary to generate random words like 'snuffle' and add bug on the end. There will be a few hundred of those .com's not taken for a start.

Author: blogimus
Content:
Bugbear.com is also not a commercial site, it is a guy's personal web presence. I would think that this would be a factor in the value of the bugbear.net name, especially for something homebrew or community oriented. If he ever did sell to a corporate body then, of course, that would change the dynamics.

Edit: I just noticed a sibling thread talking about bugbear.com being PG's site. Just random luck on my part. Bugbear just came to mind as a defect tracking product name.

Author: aggieben
Content:
Switch to an ARM or PPC chip, and it's a completely
  different process.
Yup. That's why you should do it for learning purposes - getting your head around how a machine bootstraps itself is, to my mind, one of the harder things to understand about a computing system. Part of that is because someone who doesn't know how it works might look at booting mechanisms as a sort of "black box", or just magic. Once you peer into the black box and understand some of it, suddenly, none of it seems all that mysterious anymore, even if you've only learned the particulars for one specific machine.
